HM101.name: Introduction to Public Health
HM101.description: Core public health philosophies and concepts. Health and disease – measures, determinants, health promotion and disease prevention. Introduction to health care delivery systems. Career opportunities in public health.

HM491.name: Special Topics in Bioethics and Medical Humanities
HM491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM491.description: Special topics in ethics and humanities of health care, proposed by faculty on a group study basis.

HM501.name: Preceptorship Training
HM501.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

HM552.name: Medical School I
HM552.description: A first course in a primary care, patient centered experience, integrating necessary biomedical and social sciences and humanities with clinical skills and professional development.
HM552.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM553.name: Medical School II
HM553.description: Continuation of a primary care, patient centered experience, integrating necessary biomedical and social sciences and humanities with clinical skills and professional development. Includes selectives to develop areas of strength and remediate gaps.
HM553.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM554.name: Medical School III
HM554.description: Continuation of a set of selectives to develop areas of strength and remediate gaps. The beginning of an interdisciplinary, patient centered experience, integrating necessary biomedical and social sciences and humanities with clinical skills and professional development.
HM554.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM555.name: Medical School IV
HM555.description: Continuation of an interdisciplinary, patient centered experience, integrating necessary biomedical and social sciences and humanities with clinical skills and professional development.
HM555.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM556.name: Medical School V
HM556.description: Continuation of an interdisciplinary, patient centered experience, integrating necessary biomedical and social sciences and humanities with clinical skills and professional development. Includes selectives to develop areas of strength and remediate gaps.
HM556.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM590.name: Special Topics in Medicine
HM590.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM590.description: Special topics related to healthcare covering a wide variety of disciplines and fields
HM590.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM591.name: Special Problems in Human Medicine
HM591.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM591.description: Work under the direction of a faculty member on an experimental, theoretical, or applied problem that requires a broad, interdisciplinary approach.
HM591.restrictions: Open only to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM608.name: Sub-Specialty Clerkships
HM608.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM608.description: Hospital-and office-based clinical experiences in sub-specialties in medicine and surgery.
HM608.restrictions: Open only to graduate-professional students in College of Human Medicine.

HM609.name: Laboratory Medicine Clerkship
HM609.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM609.description: Laboratory procedures. Correlation of laboratory data with morphologic abnormalities in patients with pathophysiology.
HM609.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine or in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

HM610.name: Pathology Clerkship
HM610.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM610.description: Anatomic and clinical pathology with emphasis on clinical-pathological correlation. Conducted in pathology departments of affiliated hospitals.
HM610.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine or in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

HM611.name: Hospice Clerkship
HM611.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM611.description: Treatment and interdisciplinary team evaluation in hospice medicine. Advanced care directive processes and procedures.
HM611.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM612.name: Pain Medicine
HM612.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM612.description: Evaluation and management of pain in acute and chronic disease settings. Evidence-based principles of pain medicine. Pain pharmacology. Trigger point injections, bursa injections, joint injections, peripheral nerve blocks and injections. Pain rehabilitation, prevention and interdisciplinary management.
HM612.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM613.name: Complementary Medicine Clerkship
HM613.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM613.description: Evidence based management of disease and symptoms with complementary and alternative medicine.
HM613.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM614.name: Student-Designed Elective Clerkship
HM614.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM614.description: Customized experience of clinical science skills and knowledge. Clinical performance evaluation.
HM614.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM615.name: Global Health Experience in India
HM615.description: Rural health delivery in India. Pre-travel preparation and instruction in culture followed by experiences in pediatrics, women's health, mental health, and tropical disease.
HM615.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Human Medicine or in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

HM616.name: Radiation Oncology Clerkship
HM616.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM616.description: Diagnosis, staging, and treatment of cancers amenable to radiation therapy modalities. Indications for and complications of radiation therapy in definitive and palliative settings.
HM616.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine or in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

HM617.name: Introduction to Simulation Education Elective
HM617.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM617.description: Learn and apply educational theory to the use of simulation in medical education. Participate in a blended course to learn skills necessary to conduct training including procedural or clinical skills and/or team training.
HM617.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM618.name: Telemedicine Experiences in Rural Clinical Settings
HM618.description: Clinical, biopsycosocial, documentation, and ethical aspects of telehealth to address health conditions and patient needs.
HM618.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM619.name: Clinical Knowledge, Ethics, Epidemiology in Pandemics
HM619.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM619.description: Survey of clinical knowledge and principles of necessary science, epidemiology, economics, ethics, and public health policy required in primary and tertiary health care settings during pandemics.
HM619.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM620.name: Clinical Bioethics
HM620.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM620.description: Complex bioethical issues including pandemics, physician aid-in-dying, futility/non-beneficial care, and treatment refusal by competent patients.
HM620.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM622.name: Medical Partners in Public Health Community Resources and Wellness Programs
HM622.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM622.description: Systematic exploration of community resources culminating in the construction and implementation of evidence-based and feasible community programming.

HM623.name: Medical Partners in Public Health Capstone Project Elective
HM623.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM623.description: Practical application of public health principles, epidemiology, biostatistics, health and public policy, public health administration, health behavior, health education, and environmental health.

HM624.name: Medical Humanities
HM624.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM624.description: Reflection on professional medical practice by employing the skills and perspectives of the humanities, specifically literary studies, visual and performing arts.
HM624.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM625.name: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer, Intersex, Asexual+ Health Care (Interim New)
HM625.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM625.description: LGBTQIA+ history and culture, identification of own biases, and skills in engaging the LGBTQIA+ community in a clinical setting.
HM625.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM626.name: Special Topics in Neurologic Conditions (Interim New)
HM626.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM626.description: Case-based overview of common neurologic conditions, diagnosis, treatment.
HM626.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM629.name: Leadership in Medicine for the Underserved Community Elective
HM629.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM629.description: Culturally appropriate, patient centered, and community-based experience working with underserved populations.

HM631.name: Leadership in Medicine for Underserved Urban or Global Elective
HM631.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM631.description: Patient centered and community-based experience working with an urban and/or international underserved population.

HM632.name: Rural Community Health
HM632.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM632.description: Patient centered and community based experience in rural medicine and rural medical health systems.

HM633.name: Advanced Rural Community Health
HM633.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM633.description: Advanced clinical skills, knowledge, and experience in rural patient medicine, rural community medicine, and rural medical health systems.

HM635.name: Core Competencies I
HM635.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM635.description: Core knowledge and skills from an interdisciplinary perspective.
HM635.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM636.name: Core Competencies II
HM636.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM636.description: Core knowledge and skills from an interdisciplinary perspective.
HM636.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM637.name: Core Competencies III
HM637.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM637.description: Core knowledge and skills from an interdisciplinary perspective.
HM637.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM639.name: Northern Wilderness, Emergency and Sports Medicine
HM639.description: Development of knowledge, skills and attitudes to address the needs of patients outside of the hospital with wilderness or sports related injuries.
HM639.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Human Medicine. Approval of college.

HM640.name: Service Learning In the Community
HM640.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM640.description: Demonstrate preparation and planning to provide services which respond to community need. Participate for 40 hours with community organization. Demonstrate reflectivity on participation in services.
HM640.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM641.name: Clinical Skills Competence Experience
HM641.description: Review of communication skills, history-taking, and physical examination skills in faculty-observed patient encounters.

HM642.name: Critical Care in the Late Clinical Experience
HM642.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM642.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine. Approval of college.

HM643.name: Critical Care Experience
HM643.description: Virtual learning experience in evaluating and managing acutely ill patients
HM643.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM651.name: Advanced Skills and Knowledge in Medical School I
HM651.description: Interdisciplinary small group course for advanced medical students combining advanced clinical skills with deep exploration of scientific and humanities literature underlying these skills.
HM651.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM652.name: Advanced Skills and Knowledge in Medical School II
HM652.description: Interdisciplinary small group course for advanced medical students combining advanced clinical skills with deep exploration of scientific and humanities literature underlying these skills.
HM652.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM653.name: Advanced Skills and Knowledge in Medical School III
HM653.description: Interdisciplinary small group course for advanced medical students combining advanced clinical skills with deep exploration of scientific and humanities literature underlying these skills.
HM653.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM654.name: Advanced Skills and Knowledge in Medical School IV
HM654.description: Advanced medical students combining advanced clinical skills with deep exploration of scientific and humanities literature underlying these skills.
HM654.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM655.name: Advanced Skills and Knowledge in Medical School V
HM655.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HM655.description: Interdisciplinary small group course for advanced medical students combining advanced clinical skills with deep exploration of scientific and humanities literature underlying these skills.
HM655.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM691.name: Research Clerkship
HM691.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM691.description: Data gathering, analysis, interpretation, and presentation of a biological, behavioral, or clinical research project.
HM691.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine. Approval of college.

HM801.name: Introduction to Public Health
HM801.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM801.description: Introduction to public health philosophy and core knowledge areas. Ethical, legal and political considerations. Emphasis on principles and tools for population health, disease prevention and health promotion, health determinants, healthcare and public health systems.
HM801.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or in the Public Health Graduate Certificate.

HM802.name: Biostatistics for Public Health
HM802.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM802.description: Practical applications and methods using software (SAS, Epi-Info) for statistical analysis, database construction, data visualization and interpretation
HM802.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or in the Public Health Graduate Certificate.

HM803.name: Epidemiology and Public Health
HM803.description: Distributions and determinants of disease in population. Epidemiologic research, quantitative methods, study designs pros/cons.
HM803.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Public Health major or in the Public Health Specialization.

HM804.name: Public Health Policy and Administration
HM804.description: Structural, operational, leadership and components of health policy and public health administration. Community health assessment, advocacy and evaluation within public health agencies and programs. Major business systems used for administration of public health agencies and programs.
HM804.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Public Health Major.

HM805.name: Social and Behavioral Aspects of Public Health
HM805.description: Concepts and methods of social and behavioral sciences applied to public health problems and issues.
HM805.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Public Health major or in the Public Health Specialization.

HM806.name: Environmental Factors of Health
HM806.description: Biological, physical and chemical factors that affect health of populations. Regulatory approaches to environmental hazards. Potential impact of environmental agents on health and preventive management approaches.
HM806.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Public Health major or in the Public Health Specialization.

HM807.name: Practical Application and Critical Thinking in Public Health
HM807.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM807.description: Critical thinking, reading skills, explanations, problem solving, and decision making in public health using case studies. Questioning assumptions, identifying bias, determining causality, and application of the scientific method. Reporting guidelines and systematic literature reviews.
HM807.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM808.name: Public Health Surveillance
HM808.description: Introduction, history, and design of national, state and local public health surveillance systems for communicable diseases, chronic diseases, birth defects, injury, and disasters. Use of surveillance data sources.
HM808.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM810.name: GIS and Public Health
HM810.description: Introduction to the application of geographic information science (GIS) and geography in public health. Spatial representation, visualization, exploration, and analysis of public health data using GIS.
HM810.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM815.name: Introduction to Public Health Laboratory Data for Public Health Specialists
HM815.description: Develops analytic and assessment skills; lab test performance and interpretation; pathophysiological basis of abnormal test results for public health specialists to integrate laboratory data into public health programs and products.
HM815.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM817.name: Population Healthcare Analytics
HM817.description: Introduction to healthcare analytics, the healthcare industry and the synergy between the two. Data manipulation, analyses and presentation of results. Highlights peculiarities, irregularities, and limitations of the healthcare industry and related data. Analytic tools and techniques used to create descriptive reports and predictive insights.
HM817.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM819.name: American Healthcare Delivery: A Systems Approach
HM819.description: Evolution of United States healthcare system. The Affordable Care Act (ACA). Overview of funding and costs of healthcare delivery. Effect of ACA on future healthcare delivery and health professions.
HM819.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM824.name: SAS Programming for Population Health Analytics
HM824.description: SAS programming skills for the access and management of administrative healthcare data; delivers data management training in health strategies for leaders in the growing field of unstructured information processing.
HM824.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM825.name: Transition to Graduate Academic Writing (Interim New)
HM825.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM825.description: Identify, analyze, and incorporate scholarly articles and published research studies to develop and organize writing skills within the genre of academic writing and scholarship.

HM827.name: Principles of Public Health Leadership
HM827.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM827.description: Context, competencies and core leadership skills. Theories and research in public health and related organizations. Best practices, leadership styles, professional identity. Future leadership challenges.
HM827.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM828.name: Community Engagement in Public Health Practice
HM828.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM828.description: Methods, ethics, and issues in community engaged practice and scholarship.
HM828.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Public Health Major.

HM830.name: Practical Applications of Public Health Law
HM830.description: Overview of legal basis of public health authority. Use of law to direct public health practice.
HM830.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM831.name: Communicable Disease in Public Health
HM831.description: Fundamentals of communicable disease transmission. Overview of methods for prevention and control of communicable disease. Agents and organisms of public health significance.
HM831.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM832.name: Global Public Health
HM832.description: Factors and dynamics that affect global public health. Application of public health principles and policies in international settings. Key international stakeholders and their roles in global public health.
HM832.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM833.name: Introduction to Pharmaceutical Counterfeiting and Public Health
HM833.description: General principles of counterfeiting, counterfeit pharmaceuticals, and how it affects public health. Scope, policy, supply chain management, and health effects are examined using current case examples.
HM833.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM834.name: Advanced Counterfeit Pharmaceuticals: Analysis and Assessment
HM834.description: Advanced topics on the impact of counterfeit pharmaceuticals on public health.
HM834.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM835.name: Independent Study in Public Health
HM835.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM835.description: Independent study in areas relevant to public health.
HM835.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM836.name: Comparative Global Healthcare Systems
HM836.description: Public health and culture, environment, psychosocial and economic issues. Healthcare systems and health policies. Community health assessments.
HM836.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM837.name: Poverty and Public Health
HM837.description: Concepts of health and poverty and their interrelatedness from a global and public health perspective. Roles of international agencies, national policy, gender, socioeconomic status, race, ethnicity, culture, access to resources, and conflict. Role of public health programs in the achievement and maintenance of healthy populations. Struggle to eliminate poverty.
HM837.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM838.name: Cultural Aspects of Public Health Practice
HM838.description: Cultural concepts that shape health and illness. Major issues and trends in global health. Cultural and socioeconomic factors related to work with diverse populations. Applications for public health practice.
HM838.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM839.name: Water and Public Health: A Global Perspective
HM839.description: Role of water in public health, focusing on the global crisis of water quantity and quality.Specific water “hot spots” primarily the Middle East, Africa, Asia, the Western and Southern U.S., and Mexico.
HM839.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or in the Public Health Specialization or approval of college.

HM840.name: Public Health Finance
HM840.description: Issues surrounding financial administration of health service organizations. Pragmatic side of healthcare finance, incorporating healthcare economics.
HM840.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM841.name: Public Health Policy
HM841.description: U.S. healthcare delivery and financing systems and their contributions to improving health status.
HM841.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or in the Public Health Specialization or approval of college.

HM842.name: Introduction to Public Health Informatics
HM842.description: Survey of information technology applications in the public health domain, functions and tools used to generate public health knowledge. Disease surveillance platforms and web-based public health education, ethical and legal issues surrounding data exchange.
HM842.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM843.name: Methods in Public Health Informatics
HM843.description: Theory, processes and applications of management information systems and how they relate to public health management, project management skills for information system implementation and evaluation
HM843.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM844.name: Legal/Ethical Issues in Public Health Informatics
HM844.description: Focus on legal-ethical parameters affecting application of health technology.
HM844.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM845.name: Informatics and Information Technology
HM845.description: Information technology for health informatics systems, principles of relational database systems, operations, information systems, data sets, data standards and classification systems.
HM845.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM846.name: Advanced Topics in Public Health Informatics Management
HM846.description: Research, evaluation and applications of informatics in public health and public health research.
HM846.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM847.name: Public Health in Ghana: Methods for Community Practice
HM847.description: Overview of major public health issues and the health care system, both Western and traditional, in Ghana. Health status indicators and determinants; major programs/strategies; organization of the health care system, access to and payment for care; role, image and status of health care providers; interface between Western and traditional medicine; basic qualitative and quantitative field research methods for community health.
HM847.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major and open to juniors or seniors. Approval of college; application required.

HM848.name: Preparation for Public Health in Ghana: Methods for Community Practice
HM848.description: Preparation for public health study abroad experiences in Ghana.

HM852.name: Outbreak Investigations in Public Health
HM852.description: Process for conducting public health outbreak investigations including the role of local, state, federal and international agencies. Legal, political, media and law enforcement issues.
HM852.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM853.name: Public Health Program/Intervention Evaluation
HM853.description: Introduce public health program evaluation methods/tools. Causal inference criteria, standard evaluation guides, procedural and outcome evaluation methods and needs assessment and performance monitoring methods. Integrates epidemiology, biostatistics and public health knowledge pertaining to program evaluation.
HM853.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM854.name: Health Equity Framework For Public Health Practice
HM854.description: Social justice and health equity framework for the practice of public health with analysis of persistent health disparity across race, class, gender, and other forms of difference.
HM854.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or in the Public Health Specialization or approval of college.

HM859.name: Making a Community Diagnosis I: Fundamentals
HM859.description: Concept and methods used in conducting community assessments (nationally and globally) – exploring key health indicators, environmental factors and community resources used to identify problems in a population.
HM859.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM860.name: Migrant, Refugee and Mobile Populations: Impact on Public Health
HM860.description: Core public health issues prevalent and sometimes elusive in immigrant, refugee and mobile populations. Historical context, health care delivery, access and other barriers to preventive care, social justice, cultural competence, health policy, program challenges, measurement and data assimilation.
HM860.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM861.name: Introduction to Public Health Nutrition
HM861.description: Biological principles of nutrition and physical activity with public health focus. Nutritional issues in specific populations. Introduction to malnutrition, current issues in nutrition, role of nutrition in chronic diseases, and nutrition policy and intervention programs.
HM861.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM862.name: Global Pandemics and Public Health Systems, Law, and Community Impacts (Interim New)
HM862.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HM862.description: Public Health Systems and Response to Pandemics including Public Health Law and Ethics, Disease Transmission, Testing and Treatment, and Social and Community Context.
HM862.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major and open to juniors or seniors and open to graduate students. Approval of college.

HM863.name: Parasitic Diseases and Public Health in Developing Countries
HM863.description: Nature, impact and control of parasitic diseases in developing countries.
HM863.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM864.name: Intersections of Human and Animal Health
HM864.description: Epidemiology and preventive medicine disease control methods for the control of infectious diseases and environmental health issues shared by animals and people.
HM864.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM865.name: Vitamins and Minerals: Risks to Public Health
HM865.description: Introduction to public health issues in vitamin and mineral nutrition, including biological roles, human requirements, and consequences of deficiency and excesses. Current issues regarding specific micronutrient status in U.S. and worldwide. Current and proposed population-based interventions.
HM865.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM866.name: U.S. Healthcare Access and Delivery for Migrant, Refugee, and Mobile Populations
HM866.description: Impact and challenges posed to U.S. Public Health system by migrant, refugee and mobile populations entering the United States and core public health issues they face. Barriers to prevention including health care access and delivery, social justice, cultural and language competence, workplace and environmental factors. Issues in measurement and data assimilation.
HM866.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM868.name: Integrated Research Study Design and Informatics
HM868.description: Introduction to clinical trial phases, research design, informatics aims, informatics platforms and datum lifecycle.
HM868.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM869.name: Psychiatry and Public Health: A Bio-Psycho-Social Perspective
HM869.description: Overview of common psychiatric diagnoses across the ages highlighting sociological and economic determinants of treatment and outcomes.
HM869.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM871.name: Vaccine Preventable Diseases of Public Health Importance
HM871.description: Vaccine-preventable diseases of importance to the public health and the global community. Basic epidemiology, surveillance, vaccine updates, status of the vaccination programs, associated cost, benefits, and related public health policies. Current controversies associated with national and international disease control, elimination, and eradication campaigns.
HM871.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM872.name: Global Public Health in Action
HM872.description: Qualitative research methods and analysis using case studies in national and international public health. Development of a case study.
HM872.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM873.name: Maternal and Child Health: A Global Public Health Perspective
HM873.description: Introduction to historical and cultural foundations of maternal and child global public health. Health care needs, health determinants and disparities, programs, policies and public health issues affecting women and children.
HM873.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM876.name: Nutrition and Chronic Diseases: Living Longer and Healthier
HM876.description: Role of nutrition and physical activity in chronic diseases with emphasis on macronutrients. Relationship between obesity and health and socioeconomic disparities in the United States and current policies. Overview of nutrition transition and impact on developing nations.
HM876.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM877.name: Public Health Nutrition and the Life Stages
HM877.description: Effect of nutrition on growth and development. Role of public health interventions throughout life. Emphasis on at-risk populations in the United States and worldwide. Survey of current programs addressing specific public health nutrition concerns.
HM877.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM878.name: Applied Biostatistics for Public Health Practitioners
HM878.semester: Fall of even years, Spring of every year
HM878.description: Intermediate techniques and applications of multivariable logistic and linear regression in public health. Interpretation of statistical models.
HM878.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or in the Public Health Graduate Certificate.

HM880.name: Study Design and Research Methods for Public Health Practice
HM880.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM880.description: Examination of empirical and logical basis of public health research. Identification of research questions, study design, data collection and qualitative and quantitative approaches. Reporting of findings. Proposal writing. Ethical considerations in research.
HM880.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM881.name: Pathogenesis of Parasitic Infections Important to Public Health
HM881.description: Specific causes and progression of major parasitic diseases important to global public health; diverse aspects of the host’s responses to the invasion by these organisms; protective and pathogenic immune responses; development of clinical disease; role of chemotherapy development of clinical disease; effects of chemotherapeutic agents; epidemiological discussion of the importance of quantification of the pathology and clinical disease seen in populations.
HM881.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM882.name: Public Health Nutrition: Assessment and Development of Population-Based Interventions
HM882.description: Assessment of nutritional and physical activity on a population level. Identification of at-risk populations. Collection, interpretation and application of data for developing interventions and evaluating behavior change and health outcomes. Role of public health and national nutrition institutions.
HM882.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM883.name: Mobile Health, Social Media and Games in Public Health
HM883.description: Utilization and critical analysis of mobile technology, social media platforms and games to assess, implement and improve public health programs and community education.
HM883.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health Major or approval of college.

HM885.name: Health Information Technology and Telehealth Technologies as Applied to Public Health
HM885.description: Introduction to health information technology and health information systems in healthcare and public health industries. Telehealth, eHealth, and mobile technologies for health (mHealth).
HM885.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM886.name: Public Health Diagnosis and Interpretation of Parasitic Infections
HM886.description: Current approaches in the detection, measurement and field interpretation of parasitic infections at the individual level and community level.
HM886.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM887.name: Control and Eradication of Parasitic Infections of Public Health Importance
HM887.description: Control programs, elimination/eradication of parasitic diseases of public health importance in developing countries.
HM887.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM888.name: Field Methodology for Investigating Parasitic Diseases of Public Health Importance
HM888.description: Financial, personal, and logistical aspects of control programs for parasitic diseases. Practical applications in field methods.
HM888.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM889.name: Applied Epidemiologic Methods for Public Health Practitioners
HM889.description: Identification and conceptualization of public health problems. Generation of testable hypotheses and appropriate data sets. Interpretation of appropriate measures of associations. Evaluation of validity and generalizability of results and ethical issues surrounding the use of humans in epidemiological research. Real case studies are used to analyze study design including the role of chance, bias, misclassification, effect measure modification, interaction, and missing data.
HM889.restrictions: Open to students in the Public Health major or approval of college.

HM890.name: Independent Study in Bioethics
HM890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM890.description: Special projects, directed readings, and research arranged by an individual graduate student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.
HM890.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Bioethics, Humanities, and Society major. Approval of department.

HM891.name: Introduction to Public Health Practicum
HM891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM891.description: Preparatory work for practicum placement. Special projects arranged by an individual student and faculty member in areas supporting practicum placement.

HM892.name: Public Health Applied Practice Experience
HM892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

HM893.name: Public Health Integrative Learning Experience
HM893.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

HM894.name: Practicum in Bioethics
HM894.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM894.description: Observations, participation, and study of ethical and policy issues in selected health, research, or governmental settings.
HM894.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Bioethics, Humanities, and Society major. Approval of department.

HM895.name: Clinical Medicine Capstone Experience
HM895.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HM895.description: Preparation and presentation of student’s capstone project.
HM895.prerequisite: HM 552 and HM 553 and HM 554 and HM 555 and HM 556
HM895.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Human Medicine.

HM899.name: Master's Thesis Research
HM899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
